A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.
Does the concept of a/an Noetherian ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Least common multiple to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a least common multiple (LCM) in a ring involves finding an element that is a common multiple of given elements and that any other common multiple is a multiple of this element. This definition focuses on divisibility properties within the ring.

The concept of a Noetherian ring, on the other hand, relates to the structure of ideals within the ring, specifically that every ascending chain of ideals stabilizes or that every ideal is finitely generated. This property ensures certain algebraic finiteness conditions but does not directly influence the existence or definition of LCMs.

Therefore, the existence or definition of LCMs in a ring does not inherently require the ring to be Noetherian. The definition of LCM can be applied in any ring where divisibility is well-defined, regardless of whether the ring is Noetherian or not. Thus, the concept of a Noetherian ring is not necessary for the definition of an LCM to make sense.
